On Monday 06 June 2005 16:52, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of Chris Dollin
> >
> > > Yes. Even worse: two possibly overlapping, but often  disjoint, sets of
> > > test fixture objects in the same test case class. Some tests use
> > > fixture A and others use fixture B. Why not put those in separate test
> > > case classes for clarity?
> >
> > Because of the activation energy required to split off a new
> > class, move the right methods into it, remember to link it
> > into the next level up, add it to change control, fix the
> > pesky layout infelicities the IDE likes to avoid providing a
> > configure-out option for, refactor the class comments, etc?
>
> This kind of problem is exactly why categories of tests should be a concept
> that is completely separate from the package, class or even method name.

I don't see why.

> In other words, you should be able to specify the following two concepts:
>
> - The name of the method
> - The class they belong to
> - The packages your classes belong to
>
> and
>
> - The category of your tests
>
> in an orthogonal way.

If the IDE supported test-splitting as a refactoring, the activation energy
would drop to zeroish. Since I'd want a test-splitting refactoring even if
test groups were done by annotation, and I'd expect the machinery of test-
splitting to be useful in other ways, I don't think it's a strong argument
for the annotation approach.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
